body:
Hm, how would that work exactly? The standard orientation is `'items'` but `'minor'` will work too. When you `orient='minor'` it's basically like

`Panel.from_dict(data).swapaxes(0, 2)`

but without losing the type information. Setting an attribute seems like a pretty ad hoc solution to keeping track of what code you've written, no?

Ordinarily I use panels like everybody else, i.e. item orientation.
Sometimes however, I use minor orientation because it may be important to
keep dtype information. But in both cases they contain the same type of
information. Then I have written some functions that work on these Panels
and produce further output. Either I tell them the orientation of the
panel, or they get it by themselves from the Panel.

To get more specific, my panels are usually portfolios, ie one DataFrame
for each date, major are assets, minor are portfolio weights (eg long and
short weights). In this case, item orientation is fine because all data is
float. In other circumstances, my portfolio dataframes include additional
info (stock sectors, currency etc.), so here my data is mixed type and I
tend to use minor orientation.
Then I have a function that evaluates these portfolios, ie calculates nav
series, and this should handle both cases transparently. Right now this
function has a parameter that tells orientation of passed panel.

You are right, this might seem ad hoc for my situation, but on the other
hand it just gives the object's user a piece of information on how it was
constructed and would allow for better overall consistency.

Thanks
Chris
